key_findings: Token-aware data imputation method using structured group-wise CSV-style prompting significantly reduces input prompt size while maintaining or improving imputation quality, particularly effective for smaller datasets with class imbalance.

Elimination of irrelevant contextual information from input prompts improves LLM performance in data imputation tasks, demonstrating that prompt optimization is crucial for synthetic data generation quality.

In-context learning capabilities of large language models can be effectively leveraged for tabular data imputation in class-imbalanced binary classification datasets through careful prompt engineering.

The approach addresses the critical gap in LLM-based data imputation for class-imbalanced datasets with missing data by providing a practical solution that combines structured prompting with context filtering.
Prompt design has significant impact on synthetic tabular data generation quality, establishing the importance of systematic prompt optimization for LLM-based data augmentation tasks.
limitations: Testing limited to only two class-imbalanced binary classification datasets
Effectiveness primarily demonstrated on relatively smaller datasets
future_work: Extension to multi-class classification problems and larger datasets
problem_addressed: Data imputation for class-imbalanced tabular datasets with missing values using large language models
real_world_applications: Synthetic tabular data generation for machine learning
Missing data imputation in classification tasks
